newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish depo market squeezed, zloty just firmer.
newsitem.headline: Polish depo market squeezed, zloty just firmer.

text.p: The Polish one-day deposit market was squeezed for cash on Wedesday and rates rose as banks borrowed money to pay for T-bills bought at Monday's auction.
Dealers said bank accounts were also shortened by Tuesday's central bank drainage operations, which cleared 823 million zlotys from the market through a reverse repo and bill sale.
"The wind was knocked out of the market by T-bill payments and recent drainage operations," said Malgorzata Sikora from ING Bank in Warsaw.
Overnight rates closed at 18.80/19.30 percent, up from opening at 18.80/19.20 and Tuesday's close at 18.70/19.10.
Tomorrow/next rates closed at 19.20/19.70 percent, up from 19.20/19.45 percent at opening and Tuesday's 18.80/19.20.
Dealers said the rise in T/N rates might signal that the market's tightness would carry over to Thursday, despite the early stage of Septbember's required reserve period.
"There is no reason to bid so high during the first few days of the new reserve period," ING's Sikora said.

Turnover on the secondary market was small, with trade focusing on 273-day NBP-bills, quoted at 19.90/19.70 percent, roughly half a point above the yield of a comparable 39-week T-bill in secondary trade.
Dealers said regular NBP-bill auctions kept the market flooded with high-yielding 273-day bills, last sold at an average yield of 19.83 percent.
"The NBP wants the commercial banks to buy its higher yielding paper instead of T-bills as a part of its monetary policy," said Pawel Sadalski from ABN AMRO Bank (Polska) SA.
The zloty firmed a fraction against the currency basket, and after a live session with many sellers and buyers.
It closed at 1.75/1.70 percent from the trading band centre, just stronger Tuesday's close at 1.71/1.67 percent.
"There were many transactions today but no clear trend formed," said Jaroslaw Mikolajczyk, forex dealer at Bank Amerykanski w Polsce SA.
It was at 2.7480/90 to the dollar, up from 2.7495/05 on Tuesday and at 1.8496/07 to the mark, just down from 1.8492/02.
